puzzle-2.notes:
This works by shifting each letter in the message (the plaintext) along by a fixed amount (known as the shift value) to produce the ciphertext. For example, if the shift value was 3 then the word “HELLO” would become “KHOOR”, with each letter shifted 3 to the right. 

It can be deciphered by shifting each letter in the ciphertext “KHOOR” -3 (i.e. shifting each letter 3 to the left) to return the plaintext “HELLO”. 

Even without knowing the shift value Caesar ciphers can be broken either by trying out each of the 26 possible options for the shift value or using frequency analysis. Frequency analysis is looking at the frequency of the letters that occur in the ciphertext and comparing it to the frequency of letters in the English language. 

This method is named after Julius Caesar who used it in his correspondence.

puzzle-3.plaintext: THE QUICK BROWN FOX JUMPS OVER THE LAZY DOG
puzzle-3.notes:
This works by shifting each letter in the message (the plaintext) along by a fixed amount (known as the shift value) to produce the ciphertext. For example, if the shift value was 3 then the word “HELLO” would become “KHOOR”, with each letter shifted 3 to the right. 

It can be deciphered by shifting each letter in the ciphertext “KHOOR” -3 (i.e. shifting each letter 3 to the left) to return the plaintext “HELLO”. 

Even without knowing the shift value Caesar ciphers can be broken either by trying out each of the 26 possible options for the shift value or using frequency analysis. Frequency analysis is looking at the frequency of the letters that occur in the ciphertext and comparing it to the frequency of letters in the English language. 

This method is named after Julius Caesar who used it in his correspondence.

puzzle-4.notes:
The Atbash cipher works by substituting every ‘a’ with a ‘z’, every ‘b’ with a ‘y’ etc. For example, “CAT” would become “XZG”. 

The name comes from the Hebrew alphabet, from the names of the first, last, second and second-to-last letters (Aleph-Tav-Bet-Shin).
